why: Across runs, LLM1’s arousal/valence estimates are closer to ground truth more often than LLM2’s and its responses are usually context-appropriate.
LLM2 frequently mirrors LLM1’s affect errors, tends to under-read arousal (especially in high-intensity negative states) and sometimes omits predictions (null), reducing calibration quality.
Both models show a positivity bias (valence too high/less negative) and arousal underestimation, but LLM2’s errors are typically larger or more frequent.
notable_exceptions: In some happy/fearful cases LLM2 matches or slightly improves one metric (e.g., exact happy A/V matches or closer arousal), but these are exceptions.

2_llm1_inappropriate_patterns: Misses concrete user requests (especially ‘help me choose a new alarm clock’): provides empathy but no practical assistance or questions.
Softens or mislabels core emotions: disgust/anger → frustration/unease; fear → worry/uncertainty; sadness → disappointment; often underestimates intensity.
Ignores salient safety/context cues (slick surface, jacket reminder, storm risk) or makes wrong assumptions (rain vs. cold, health issues, ankle injury).
Tone too mild for high-arousal negative states (airport delays at night, missed meeting/party, anger/disgust scenes) resulting in under-validated distress.
3_llm2_decision_errors: Overuses ‘defer’ in low-risk, socially safe contexts; often labels LLM1 ‘inappropriate’ and then defers—an inconsistent pattern.
Approves ‘respond’ when LLM1 missed actionable needs (alarm clock help), ignored safety cues, or misread high intensity (anger/fear/disgust).
Provides no numeric affect predictions in some trials (null), weakening supervisory value.
Systematically underestimates arousal (especially high-arousal negative states) and overestimates valence; fails to nudge LLM1 toward stronger validation or concrete steps.
4_llm2_judgement_errors_of_llm1: Incorrectly flags appropriate LLM1 replies as ‘inappropriate’ and defers (frequent across emotions, including fear/sad/neutral).
Overly lenient approvals: marks LLM1 ‘appropriate’ even when LLM1 ignores a practical request (alarm clock), misses safety reminders (slick/jacket), or downplays intensity (anger/disgust/fear).
Mirrors LLM1’s affect miscalibration instead of correcting (e.g., neutral read as positive; high-arousal anger/disgust read as mild).
5_other_insights: Global biases: both models underestimate arousal and make valence less negative in negative emotions; they soften anger→frustration and disgust→discomfort.
Disgust is the hardest emotion: often mislabeled as frustration/unease with valence too high and arousal too low; improvements needed in naming disgust and offering aversion-respecting options.
High-arousal negative scenarios (anger/fear/sad at night/urgent) are routinely under-read; replies should explicitly acknowledge intensity and add concrete steps (apology/repair, safety guidance).
Neutral states: both drift positive (valence too high) or add unnecessary reassurance; better to keep brief, neutral acknowledgments and address practical cues.
Task/safety grounding boosts appropriateness: best responses acknowledge situational details (jacket, slick surfaces, storm, rebooking/rescheduling) plus emotion.
LLM2’s supervision frequently mirrors LLM1’s errors; when LLM2 is better, it’s typically by small margins on a single metric rather than overall calibration.
LLM1’s content quality is generally empathetic and acceptable; key gaps are intensity calibration, explicit emotion naming (esp. disgust/anger), and addressing concrete requests.
